## ğŸ¤ Our Standards

- Be respectful and inclusive â€” no harassment or discrimination  
- Assume good intent; provide constructive feedback  
- Accept critique gracefully; disagree without hostility  
- Collaborate openly and transparently  
- Recognize contributions from all community members  

---

## ğŸš« Unacceptable Behavior

- Harassment, insults, or derogatory comments  
- Discriminatory language or exclusionary behavior  
- Public or private intimidation, stalking, or threats  
- Disruptive trolling or deliberate derailment of discussions  
- Sharing sensitive information without consent  

---

## ğŸ“‘ Community Expectations

Kansas-Frontier-Matrix has additional norms rooted in our **Master Coder Protocol (MCP)** and project culture:

- **Reproducibility first** â†’ every dataset, experiment, or workflow must be documented and reproducible  
- **Documentation-driven development** â†’ README files, SOPs, and schemas are living lab notebooks, not afterthoughts  
- **Provenance matters** â†’ checksums, STAC metadata, and logs ensure traceability across time and space  
- **Transparency in decisions** â†’ roadmap, governance, and design discussions are captured in issues/PRs  
- **Respect for history & culture** â†’ Indigenous perspectives, oral traditions, and archival integrity are treated with care  
- **Collaboration over competition** â†’ reviewers, maintainers, and contributors work as peers in a shared knowledge hub

ğŸ§­ Maintainer Guidelines

Maintainers are expected to model MCP values in addition to enforcing conduct:
	â€¢	Documentation-first â†’ every new feature, workflow, or dataset must include or update a README/schema
	â€¢	Reproducibility â†’ ensure changes can be regenerated from make targets; avoid one-off/manual work
	â€¢	Provenance â†’ all new data requires checksums, STAC items, or metadata sidecars
	â€¢	CI hygiene â†’ workflows must be pinned, least-privilege, and artifact outputs must be validated
	â€¢	Transparency â†’ design and governance decisions logged in issues/PRs, not in private chats
	â€¢	Mentorship â†’ guide contributors in MCP practices (schemas, provenance, docs)
	â€¢	Consistency â†’ enforce branch protection, review rigor, and coding/documentation standards

By following these guidelines, maintainers uphold both the social trust and the technical integrity of the project.

â¸»

âš™ï¸ How This Links to CI

Contributor behavior and MCP alignment are tied directly to automation:
	â€¢	Respectful, well-documented contributions â†’ faster reviews and smoother merges
	â€¢	Reproducibility and provenance â†’ fewer CI failures (STAC validate, schema checks, provenance hashes)
	â€¢	CI hygiene â†’ automerge eligibility once all required checks pass
	â€¢	Transparency in PRs â†’ better roadmap syncing and milestone tracking

ğŸ‘‰ In short: good conduct = smoother pipelines = faster integration.
